importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report reflects the most recent update on the evolving death toll and recovery efforts following the flooding event in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred last week, indicating a recent and active natural disaster that has led to significant loss of life and infrastructure damage.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported that 65 people remain missing.
Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
Early estimates indicate about 100,000 houses have been affected, with some homes near rivers nearly destroyed.
The flooding was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for approximately 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no early meteorological warnings indicating the severity of the rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered a major flooding disaster in recent days, with at least 64 fatalities and 65 people still missing across five states, primarily Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla. The event, triggered by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, brought unprecedented rainfall—up to 286mm in Cuetzalan del Progreso and 280mm in Cerro Azul—leading to river overflows, landslides, and widespread destruction. Thousands of military personnel have been deployed to provide emergency aid, including food and clean water, while nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to affected areas. The government has acknowledged a lack of early meteorological warnings that could have predicted the severity of the rains, raising concerns about disaster preparedness and early alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
